questions.text: Which neuroendocrine tumor (NET) is most likely to be associated with malignancy?
questions.solution:
Option A (Insulinoma): Incorrect. While insulinomas are the most common NET of the pancreas, they are usually benign (90-95%). Only a small percentage exhibit malignant behavior.

Option B (Gastrinoma): Correct. Gastrinomas are highly associated with malignancy. Approximately 60-90% of gastrinomas are malignant, with potential for metastasis, especially to the liver and lymph nodes.

Option C (VIPoma): Incorrect. VIPomas, though rare, are malignant in about 50-60% of cases. However, the malignancy rate is lower compared to gastrinomas.

Option D (Somatostatinoma): Incorrect. Somatostatinomas are rare, and while they are frequently malignant (about 50%), they are less common than gastrinomas and VIPomas.

Key Points:

Malignancy Risk in NETs:

  • Highest malignancy risk: Gastrinomas (60-90%).
  • Intermediate risk: VIPomas (50-60%) and Somatostatinomas (~50%).
  • Lowest risk: Insulinomas (5-10%).

Tags:

Topic: Neuroendocrine Tumors

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter-57, page number. -905.

choices.text: Associated with carcinoid syndrome only if liver metastases are present
Most commonly found in the stomach

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding midgut carcinoid tumors?
questions.solution:
Option A (Commonly metastasizes to bones): Incorrect. Bone metastases are more common with foregut carcinoid tumors, especially those originating in the lungs and stomach.

Option B (Associated with carcinoid syndrome only if liver metastases are present): Correct. Midgut carcinoid tumors produce serotonin, but it is usually metabolized by the liver. Carcinoid syndrome manifests only when liver metastases bypass hepatic metabolism, allowing serotonin to enter systemic circulation.

Option C (Negative for serotonin secretion): Incorrect. Midgut carcinoid tumors are serotonin-positive. They actively secrete serotonin, which plays a major role in carcinoid syndrome.

Option D (Most commonly found in the stomach): Incorrect. Midgut carcinoid tumors are most commonly found in the small intestine and appendix, not the stomach.

Tags:

Topic: Carcinoid Tumors

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter - 57, page number. -911

questions.text: A 50-year-old male is diagnosed with a 3.5 cm renal cell carcinoma (RCC) in his solitary kidney. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A (Radical nephrectomy): Incorrect. Radical nephrectomy is the treatment of choice for larger tumors or when nephron-sparing surgery is not feasible. However, in a solitary kidney, nephron-sparing surgery is preferred to preserve renal function.

Option B (Nephron-sparing surgery): Correct. For RCC ≤4 cm in size or in cases of a solitary kidney, nephron-sparing surgery (partial nephrectomy) is the standard treatment to preserve renal function while achieving oncological control.

Option C (Sunitinib): Incorrect. Sunitinib is the first-line therapy for metastatic RCC, not for localized disease.

Option D (IL-2 and IFN-α): Incorrect. These are second-line therapies for advanced or metastatic RCC, not indicated for localized disease.

Tags:

Topic: Renal Cell Carcinoma

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter-82, page number. -1483

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of smoking presents with painless hematuria. He works in the rubber industry and has prolonged exposure to aromatic amines. Imaging reveals a bladder mass. Which type of bladder cancer is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A (Transitional Cell Carcinoma): Correct. TCC is the most common type of bladder cancer and is strongly associated with smoking, exposure to aromatic amines, and occupational hazards such as the rubber industry.

Option B (Squamous Cell Carcinoma): Incorrect. SCC is associated with chronic irritation, such as schistosomiasis, bladder stones, or prolonged catheterization, but these factors are not present in this case.

Option C (Adenocarcinoma): Incorrect. Adenocarcinoma is rare and usually linked to urachal remnants or chronic inflammation.

Option D (Small Cell Carcinoma): Incorrect. This is an extremely rare form of bladder cancer, usually associated with aggressive disease and neuroendocrine features.

CA Bladder Risk Factors

  • Transitional cell carcinoma > Squamous cell carcinoma > Adenocarcinoma

Tags:

Topic: Bladder Cancer

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter -83, page number -1516

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder

questions.text: A 42-year-old female with a history of smoking presents with painless hematuria. Imaging reveals a polypoid lesion in the bladder. Urine cytology shows atypical cells, and cystoscopy confirms a visible tumor. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A (Urothelial carcinoma): Correct. Urothelial carcinoma is the most common type of bladder cancer, associated with smoking and painless hematuria. Polypoid lesions are characteristic, and cytology often reveals atypical cells.

Option B (Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder): Incorrect. Squamous cell carcinoma is less common and typically associated with chronic irritation (e.g., schistosomiasis, long-term catheter use).

Option C (Adenocarcinoma of the bladder): Incorrect. Adenocarcinoma is rare and associated with urachal remnants or chronic inflammation. It is not typically polypoid in presentation.

Option D (Malakoplakia): Incorrect. Malakoplakia is a rare inflammatory condition characterized by Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, not a neoplastic process.

Key Points:

  1. Bladder Cancer Overview:
    • Urothelial carcinoma (90%): Smoking, aromatic amines are major risk factors.
    • Squamous cell carcinoma (5-7%): Associated with chronic irritation or infection.
    • Adenocarcinoma (<2%): Rare, linked to urachal remnants.
  2. Painless Hematuria:
    • Always warrants investigation for bladder cancer.
  3. Diagnostic Workup:
    • Imaging: Ultrasound or CT urogram for lesion identification.
    • Cytology: Atypical or malignant cells.
    • Cystoscopy and Biopsy: Gold standard for diagnosis and staging.

Tags:

Topic: Bladder Cancer

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter -83, page number -1516

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with hematuria and a centrally located renal mass identified on imaging. The pathology reveals an aggressive tumor arising from the renal medulla. The patient has a history of sickle cell trait. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A (Clear-cell RCC): Incorrect. Although the most common RCC subtype, clear-cell RCC typically arises sporadically and does not have a strong association with sickle cell trait or a central location.

Option B (Chromophobe RCC): Incorrect. Chromophobe RCC is typically sporadic and has a good prognosis, unlike the aggressive behavior seen in this case.

Option C (Collecting duct carcinoma): Incorrect. While centrally located, collecting duct carcinoma is not strongly associated with sickle cell trait. It is aggressive but less likely in younger patients compared to renal medullary carcinoma.

Option D (Renal medullary carcinoma): Correct. This rare and aggressive subtype is strongly associated with sickle cell trait and arises from the renal medulla, presenting as a centrally located tumor.

Tags:

Topic: Renal Cell Carcinoma Subtypes

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter - 82, page number. 1482

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with severe flank pain and hematuria. Imaging reveals a 1.5 cm stone in the upper third of the ureter. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Option A (ESWL): Incorrect. While ESWL is preferred for stones ≤1 cm in the upper or middle third of the ureter, stones >1 cm in size are less effectively treated with shockwaves, making URS the better option for this case.

Option B (URS): Correct. Ureteroscopic removal of the stone is the treatment of choice for ureteric stones >1 cm, especially in the upper third of the ureter, as it provides a direct approach with high success rates.

Option C (PCNL): Incorrect. PCNL is typically used for renal stones >2 cm or complex stones like staghorn calculi, not for ureteric stones.

Option D (Open Ureterolithotomy): Incorrect. This is rarely used nowadays due to advancements in minimally invasive techniques like URS and ESWL.

  • Management of Renal Stone
    • For Stone size up to 2 cm - ESWL
    • For Stone size > 2 cm - PCNL
    • For Hard stone (BHC-2) - PCNL
    • For Staghorn calculi - Sandwich technique (PCNL + ESWL)
  • Management of Ureteric Stone
    • Depends on location of stone
    • Stone in upper and middle 1/3 of ureter
    • Size of stone up to 1 cm - ESWL > URS
    • Size of stone > 1 cm - URS
    • Stone in lower 1/3 of ureter - URS (No use of shockwaves in this area)

Tags:

Topic: Urolithiasis Management

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter- 82, page number -1477

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a motorbike accident. He complains of an inability to pass urine, and examination reveals blood at the tip of the meatus and a butterfly-shaped hematoma involving the perineum and scrotum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A (Posterior urethral injury): Incorrect. Posterior urethral injuries are typically associated with pelvic fractures and present with a deep perineal hematoma involving the anterior abdominal wall and thighs. The presence of a butterfly-shaped hematoma is specific to anterior urethral injury.

Option B (Anterior urethral injury): Correct. The clinical features, including blood at the tip of the meatus, inability to pass urine, bladder distension, and a butterfly-shaped hematoma, are characteristic of anterior urethral injury, typically resulting from direct trauma or a straddle injury.

Option C (Bladder rupture): Incorrect. Bladder rupture commonly occurs due to pelvic fractures and may present with suprapubic tenderness and gross hematuria, but it lacks the butterfly-shaped hematoma or blood at the meatus.

Option D (Penile fracture): Incorrect. Penile fractures are associated with a history of trauma during erection and present with an audible crack, immediate pain, and penile swelling, not a butterfly-shaped hematoma or blood at the meatus.

Tags:

Topic: Anterior vs. Posterior Urethral Injuries

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter -85, page number. 1541

choices.text: Sperms are present in epididymal cyst fluid
Epididymal cyst fluid shows a Chinese lantern pattern on transillumination
Spermatoceles are multilocular and resemble a bunch of grapes
Epididymal cysts are commonly found in the epididymal head

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately differentiates a spermatocele from an epididymal cyst?
questions.solution:
Option A: Incorrect. Sperms are present in the fluid of a spermatocele, not in an epididymal cyst.

Option B: Correct. Epididymal cyst fluid is crystal clear and produces a characteristic "Chinese lantern pattern" on transillumination.

Option C: Incorrect. Spermatoceles are unilocular, while epididymal cysts are multilocular, resembling a "bunch of grapes."

Option D: Incorrect. Both spermatoceles and epididymal cysts commonly involve the epididymal head, but this feature does not differentiate them.

Tags:

Topic: Scrotal Swellings, Spermatocele vs. Epididymal Cyst

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter -86, page number:1566

questions.text: Which layer of the abdominal wall does not have a corresponding continuation in the scrotum?
questions.solution:
Option A (External oblique muscle): Incorrect. The external oblique muscle continues as the external spermatic fascia in the scrotum.

Option B (Internal oblique muscle): Incorrect. The internal oblique muscle forms the cremasteric fascia and muscle in the scrotum.

Option C (Transverse abdominus muscle): Correct. The transverse abdominus muscle does not continue into the scrotum and has no corresponding layer.

Option D (Transversalis fascia): Incorrect. The transversalis fascia continues as the internal spermatic fascia in the scrotum.


Tags:

Topic: Abdominal Wall and Scrotum

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter-64, page number. 1059

questions.text: Which of the following opacities on a plain abdominal radiograph can be confused with renal calculi?
questions.solution:
Option A (Calcified mesenteric lymph node): Correct. These calcifications in the mesentery can mimic renal calculi on imaging.

Option B (Phleboliths): Correct. Phleboliths are calcifications within veins, commonly seen in the pelvis, and may be mistaken for distal ureteric calculi.

Option C (Gallstones): Correct. Gallstones or appendiceal concretions may appear as opacities in the upper abdomen, potentially mimicking renal calculi.

Option D (All of the above): Correct. All listed opacities are potential mimics of renal calculi on plain radiographs.

Opacities on a Plain Abdominal Radiograph that may be Confused with Renal Calculus

  • Calcified Mesenteric Lymph Node
  • Gallstones or concretion in the appendix
  • Tablets or Foreign bodies in the Alimentary canal (e.g., cyclopenthiazide Navidrex-K)
  • Phleboliths - calcification in the walls of veins, especially in the veins
  • Ossified tip of the 12th rib
  • Calcified tuberculous lesion in the kidney
  • Calcified adrenal gland

Tags:

Topic: Renal Calculi d/d

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter -82, page number:1474

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a prolonged, painful erection lasting over 6 hours. There is no history of trauma or medication use. Blood gas analysis from a cavernosal blood sample reveals hypoxia and acidosis. What is the most likely type of priapism and the initial step in management?
questions.solution:
Option A (High-flow priapism; observation): Incorrect. High-flow priapism is non-ischemic and often painless, usually caused by trauma, and does not show hypoxia or acidosis on blood gas analysis. Observation or embolization is the preferred approach.

Option B (Low-flow priapism; intracavernosal phenylephrine): Correct. Low-flow (ischemic) priapism is the most common type and is a urological emergency. Blood gas analysis shows hypoxia and acidosis. The first-line treatment is intracavernosal injection of an α-agonist like phenylephrine to constrict the blood vessels and reduce blood pooling.

Option C (High-flow priapism; surgical shunting): Incorrect. High-flow priapism is managed with embolization or observation and rarely requires surgical intervention.

Option D (Low-flow priapism; penile prosthesis implantation): Incorrect. Penile prosthesis is considered only for refractory cases or when there is irreversible ischemic damage.

Key Points:

  1. Low-flow (ischemic) priapism:
    • Commonly caused by conditions like sickle cell anemia, leukemia, or medications.
    • Blood gas analysis reveals hypoxia, hypercapnia, and acidosis.
    • Painful and requires urgent intervention to prevent long-term damage.
  2. High-flow (non-ischemic) priapism:
    • Caused by trauma leading to arteriovenous shunts.
    • Blood gas analysis is consistent with normal oxygenation.
    • Often painless and managed conservatively or with embolization. 
  3. Management of low-flow priapism:
    • Immediate cavernosal blood aspiration.
    • Intracavernosal phenylephrine injection.
    • Surgical intervention for refractory cases.

Tags:

Topic: Priapism

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter-85, page number. 1551

choices.text: Ureter opens above the external urethral sphincter
More common in males than females
Always associated with unilateral ureteric duplication

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of an ectopic ureter in females?
questions.solution:
Option A (Incontinence despite normal voiding): Correct. In females, the ectopic ureter typically opens below the external urethral sphincter, leading to continuous leakage of urine despite normal bladder voiding.

Option B (Ureter opens above the external urethral sphincter): Incorrect. This is characteristic of ectopic ureters in males, not females, resulting in continence.

Option C (More common in males than females): Incorrect. Ectopic ureters are more common in females with a female-to-male ratio of 7:1.

Option D (Always associated with unilateral ureteric duplication): Incorrect. Ectopic ureters are almost always associated with ureteric duplication, but 10% of cases are bilateral.

Key Points:

  1. Ectopic Ureters:
    • Drain to regions other than the bladder, such as the urethra or vagina in females and above the external sphincter in males.
    • Commonly associated with ureteric duplication.
  2. Epidemiology:
    • Female-to-male ratio: 7:1.
    • Bilateral cases occur in 10%.
  3. Clinical Features:
    • Females: Incontinence despite normal voiding due to the ureter opening below the external sphincter.
    • Males: Typically continent as the ureter opens above the sphincter.
  4. Diagnosis:
    • Imaging: Computed tomo-urography (CTU) or magnetic resonance urography (MRU) is diagnostic.

Tags:

Topic: Ectopic Ureter

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter-82, page number. 1467

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common symptom of genitourinary tuberculosis (GUTB)?
questions.solution:
Option A (Haematuria): Incorrect. Haematuria can occur in GUTB, but it is not the most common symptom.

Option B (Colicky flank pain): Incorrect. Flank pain is usually due to obstructive lesions in the kidneys or ureters and is less common than urinary frequency.

Option C (Urinary frequency): Correct. Urinary bladder involvement in GUTB is secondary to renal disease, causing fibrosis and reduced bladder capacity, leading to urinary frequency, the most common symptom.

Option D (Painless epididymal nodule): Incorrect. Epididymal involvement is a recognized presentation but is not as common as urinary frequency.

Key Points:

  1. Genitourinary Tuberculosis (GUTB):
    • Accounts for 15-20% of extrapulmonary TB cases.
    • Secondary to haematogenous spread from the lungs or thoracic lymph nodes.
  2. Pathophysiology:
    • Tubercular lesions progress to fibrosis, causing obstruction and loss of renal function
    • Bladder involvement leads to "thimble bladder" and urinary frequency.
  3. Clinical Features:
    • Urinary frequency (most common symptom).
    • Flank pain, haematuria, recurrent UTIs, and painless epididymal nodules.
  4. Diagnosis:
    • Urine tests: Acid-fast bacilli (AFB) on three consecutive morning samples, urine culture, and NAATs.
    • Imaging: IVU, CTU (calyceal distortion, papillary necrosis).
  5. Management:
    • Antitubercular Therapy (ATT): Rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide ± ethambutol.
    • Interventions: DJ stenting, PCN for strictures, reconstructive surgery for sequelae.

Tags:

Topic: Genitourinary Tuberculosis

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter-82, page number 1472

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with carcinoma of the prostate presents with a PSA level of 12 ng/mL, Gleason score of 7 (4+3), and stage T2b disease. He is otherwise healthy and wishes to pursue an aggressive treatment strategy. What is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A (Active surveillance): Incorrect. Active surveillance is suitable for low-risk disease or patients unwilling to undergo aggressive treatment. This patient has intermediate-risk disease and is fit for radical treatment.

Option B (Radical prostatectomy): Correct. Radical prostatectomy is appropriate for intermediate-risk prostate cancer in younger, healthier patients. It offers curative potential with acceptable long-term outcomes.

Option C (Androgen ablation therapy): Incorrect. Androgen ablation therapy is used in high-risk or metastatic disease, not as a first-line treatment for intermediate-risk localized prostate cancer.

Option D (Palliative radiotherapy): Incorrect. Palliative radiotherapy is reserved for metastatic disease or symptom management, not for localized intermediate-risk cancer.

Key Points:

  1. Risk-Based Management of Prostate Cancer:
    • Low-risk disease: Active surveillance or radical treatment in select younger patients (<70 years).
    • Intermediate-risk disease: Radical prostatectomy or radiotherapy in younger, fit patients; active monitoring in older or less fit individuals.
    • High-risk disease: Multimodal therapy, including androgen ablation and radiotherapy, with possible radical prostatectomy in younger patients.
    • Metastatic disease: Androgen ablation and systemic chemotherapy in symptomatic or fit individuals.
  2. Criteria for Risk Stratification:
    • PSA level.
    • Gleason score.
    • Tumor stage (T1-T3).
  3. Radical Prostatectomy:
    • Gold standard for localized or intermediate-risk prostate cancer in fit, younger patients.

Tags:

Topic: Prostate Cancer Management

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter -84, page number. 1536
